Place cells show phase precession (O'Keefe and Recce 1993) creating temporal position code. Theta-gamma coupling organizes sequential memories. (2) Gamma: PV+ basket cell/pyramidal neuron reciprocal inhibition (PING model). Each ~25ms cycle = integration window. Binding hypothesis (Singer, Gray): gamma synchronization binds features across cortical areas. Attention enhances coherence (Fries: communication through coherence). (3) Alpha: Berger rhythm from thalamocortical loops. Active inhibition of irrelevant cortical regions (Klimesch). Increases eyes-closed, desynchronizes with visual engagement. (4) SWR (150-250 Hz): CA3 bursts initiate compressed replay (10-20x faster). Disruption impairs consolidation (Girardeau 2009). Coupled with slow oscillations and spindles for systems consolidation. (5) Pathological: epilepsy (hypersynchronous), Parkinson's (excess beta in basal ganglia).

questions.question: Researchers hypothesize that hippocampal sharp-wave ripple (SWR) replay during sleep is necessary for spatial memory consolidation. Using closed-loop SWR detection and disruption, which design best tests this?
options: Use only behavioral observation
Disrupt all neural activity during sleep
Compare sleep and wake without intervention

Train rats on spatial navigation, then during post-training sleep compare: SWR-disruption (stimulation within 25ms of real-time SWR detection), random-stimulation control (same stimulation count at random NREM times), and no-stimulation control. Test next-day memory. Verify SWR disruption eliminates replay without affecting slow oscillations, spindles, or total sleep, and show no deficit when disrupting SWRs after a non-spatial task
questions.explanation: This design addresses SWR-specific consolidation: (1) Closed-loop detection: Band-pass filter 150-250 Hz, threshold-triggered stimulation within 25ms (within ~50-100ms ripple duration). Biphasic pulse to commissure/fornix disrupts coordinated replay without tissue damage. (2) Random stimulation control: Same parameters but not time-locked to SWRs. Rules out non-specific effects (arousal, stress). Only SWR-timed disruption should impair memory. (3) No-stimulation baseline. (4) Electrophysiological verification: Bayesian decoding shows degraded replay fidelity in disrupted SWRs. Other sleep features intact (slow oscillation power, spindle density, total NREM/REM). (5) Task specificity: Non-spatial task (object recognition) should be unaffected, supporting place cell replay specificity. (6) Expected: SWR-disrupted rats show impaired spatial performance while controls are normal. Replay degradation magnitude should correlate with memory impairment. Approach validated by Girardeau et al. (2009) and Ego-Stengel and Wilson (2010).

questions.question: Neural progenitor cell fate decisions during nervous system development are tightly regulated. Which statement best describes the key molecular mechanisms?
options: Neural progenitor fate is regulated by temporal transcription factor sequences: symmetric division expands the progenitor pool; Notch-Delta lateral inhibition selects neurons (low Notch/Hes1) vs. progenitors (high Notch/Hes1); proneural bHLH factors (Neurogenin, Mash1) drive neuronal commitment; a later switch from neurogenesis to gliogenesis is controlled by JAK-STAT/BMP signaling for astrocytes and Olig2/NKX2.2 for oligodendrocytes, with epigenetics progressively restricting competence
All progenitors simultaneously differentiate into neurons and glia
Neurons and glia arise from completely separate progenitor populations
Neural progenitor fate is entirely random stochastic
questions.explanation: Neural fate determination uses layered mechanisms: (1) Symmetric vs. asymmetric division: Early cells divide symmetrically (expand pool). Later, spindle orientation shifts for asymmetric divisions: one daughter maintains apical contact (radial glia) while other becomes intermediate progenitor/neuron. Controlled by LGN/NuMA/dynein and Par3/Par6/aPKC. (2) Notch-Delta: Adjacent cells express Delta and Notch. Delta activates Notch cleavage, NICD translocates to nucleus, activates Hes1/Hes5 repressing proneural genes. High-Delta/low-Notch = neurons; high-Notch/low-Delta = progenitors. Hes1 oscillates (2-3 hr period). (3) Proneural factors: Neurogenin1/2 (cortical glutamatergic), Mash1/Ascl1 (GABAergic), activating differentiation genes and cell cycle exit. (4) Neurogenesis-to-gliogenesis switch: Neurogenin sequesters CBP/p300 from STAT binding. When neurogenin wanes, JAK-STAT drives GFAP for astrocytes. BMP2/4 synergize with LIF. (5) Oligodendrocytes: Olig2 + Nkx2.2 drive OPC fate. Sox10 maintains, Myrf drives myelination. (6) Epigenetic restriction: Progressive DNA methylation limits late progenitors' neurogenic capacity. PRC2/EZH2 silences early fate genes.
